meaning: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected, typically an unwelcome one.
example: Shelley's angry retort was an aberration from her normally quiet demeanor.

meaning: Cheerful and full of energy.
example: She sounded ebullient and happy.

meaning: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
example: A cacophony of deafening alarm bells.

meaning: Bitterness or ill feeling.
example: The meeting ended with acrimony on both sides.

meaning: Demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight.
example: His bellicose behavior at the party ensured that he would not be invited again.

meaning: Given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior.
example: The capricious weather had us carrying both sunscreen and umbrellas.

meaning: Essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison.
example: The two cultures were so utterly disparate that she found it hard to adapt from one to the other.

meaning: Lasting for a very short time.
example: Fashion trends are often ephemeral, quickly replaced by new styles.

meaning: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble.
example: They spent a furtive day together.

meaning: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
example: Polonius is portrayed as a foolish, garrulous old man.

meaning: Unfortunate.
example: The hapless passengers were stranded at the airport for three days.

meaning: A person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions.
example: He was an iconoclast, a true visionary who wasn't afraid to question the status quo.

meaning: Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
example: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with some of his later works.

meaning: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements.
example: The landscape was a kaleidoscope of colors in the autumn.

meaning: Looking or sounding sad and dismal.
example: His face looked even more lugubrious than usual.

meaning: More generous than is usual or necessary.
example: A munificent gesture.

meaning: Wicked or criminal.
example: The nefarious activities of the organized-crime syndicates.

meaning: Render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible.
example: The spelling changes will deform some familiar words and obfuscate their etymological origins.

meaning: Deceitful and untrustworthy.
example: A perfidious lover.

meaning: Exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical.
example: A vast and perhaps quixotic project.

meaning: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude toward authority or discipline.
example: A class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds.

meaning: A person who acts obsequiously toward someone important in order to gain advantage.
example: He was surrounded by sycophants.

meaning: Eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant.
example: His days of truculent defiance were over.

meaning: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
example: His ubiquitous influence was felt by all the family.

meaning: Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
example: I had for a time vacillated between teaching and journalism.

meaning: Skilled at gaining an advantage, especially deceitfully.
example: His wily opponents.

meaning: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
example: The xenophobia against the foreign workers was alarming.

meaning: To join, link.
example: The oxen were yoked together.

meaning: A person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their religious, political, or other ideals.
example: The religious zealots had taken over the town.

meaning: Repeal or do away with (a law, right, or formal agreement).
example: A proposal to abrogate temporarily the right to strike.

meaning: Well meaning and kindly.
example: A benevolent smile.

meaning: Mutual trust and friendship among people who spend a lot of time together.
example: A genuine camaraderie on the hockey team.

meaning: Causing harm or damage.
example: Divorce is assumed to have deleterious effects on children.

meaning: Based on, concerned with, or verifiable by observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic.
example: They provided considerable empirical evidence to support their argument.

meaning: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor.
example: A facetious remark.

meaning: Fond of company; sociable.
example: He was a popular and gregarious man.

meaning: A lengthy and aggressive speech.
example: He delivered a harangue about the evils of popular culture.

meaning: Having little or no money.
example: A titled but impecunious family.

meaning: Feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph.
example: The jubilant winner of the contest.

meaning: Action or practice characteristic of a knave.
example: His knavery had become well-known in the town.

meaning: A lack of energy and enthusiasm.
example: Periods of weakness and lethargy.

meaning: A countless or extremely great number.
example: Networks connecting a myriad of computers.

meaning: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past.
example: I was overcome with acute nostalgia for my days in college.

meaning: Noisy and difficult to control.
example: The boy is cocky and obstreperous.

meaning: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
example: It would have taken a paragon of virtue not to feel viciously jealous.

meaning: A state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation.
example: Kate was in a quandary.

meaning: Deep respect for someone or something.
example: Rituals showed honor and reverence for the dead.

meaning: Having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment.
example: They were sagacious enough to avoid any outright confrontation.

meaning: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
example: A tenacious grip.

meaning: Take (a position of power or importance) illegally or by force.
example: Richard usurped the throne.

meaning: Regard with great respect; revere.
example: Mother Teresa is venerated as a saint.

meaning: Attractive or appealing in appearance or character.
example: A winsome smile.

meaning: Have an intense feeling of longing for something, typically something that one has lost or been separated from.
example: She yearned for a glimpse of him.

meaning: A soft gentle breeze.
example: The zephyr provided a welcome respite from the heat.

meaning: Of doubtful authenticity, although widely circulated as being true.
example: An apocryphal story about a former president.

meaning: So lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring.
example: Songs with banal, repeated words.

meaning: Having knowledge or being aware of.
example: Statesmen must be cognizant of the political boundaries within which they work.

meaning: Lack of harmony among musical notes.
example: An unusual degree of dissonance for such choral styles.

meaning: Mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation.
example: She accepted both the good and the bad with equanimity.

meaning: Intense happiness.
example: Domestic felicity.

meaning: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
example: Polonius is portrayed as a foolish, garrulous old man.

meaning: Lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
example: Hackneyed old sayings.

meaning: A person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions.
example: He was an iconoclast, a true visionary who wasn't afraid to question the status quo.

meaning: Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
example: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with some of his later works.

meaning: A constantly changing pattern or sequence of elements.
example: The landscape was a kaleidoscope of colors in the autumn.

example: His face looked even more lugubrious than usual.

example: A munificent gesture.

meaning: Wicked or criminal.
example: The nefarious activities of the organized-crime syndicates.

example: The spelling changes will deform some familiar words and obfuscate their etymological origins.

example: A perfidious lover.

example: A vast and perhaps quixotic project.

example: A class of recalcitrant fifteen-year-olds.

example: He was surrounded by sycophants.

example: His days of truculent defiance were over.

example: His ubiquitous influence was felt by all the family.

example: I had for a time vacillated between teaching and journalism.

example: His wily opponents.

example: The oxen were yoked together.

example: The religious zealots had taken over the town.
